Description: A man's face, possibly a portrait, apparently broken from a terracotta figure, but perhaps from a flask. The hair is close-cropped and side-whiskers join under the chin. It appears to be a product of a two-piece mould, but the edge, where it is unbroken, seems to be finished, rather than a separated join (but such edges can be deceptive). Micaceous brown-grey Nile silt (fired in a reducing atmosphere), with a black slip (Memphis Black Ware).
Curator's comments: Terracotta IV Purchased: Greville J. Chester. Ptolemaic, second to first century BC.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3582)
Condition: incomplete - front of the head only
Acquisition name: Purchased from: Rev Greville John Chester
